title: Safe Sex and HIV

content: The topic of sex is pretty taboo. Just the word can make people uncomfortable and cause them to blush and sweat. That makes it really difficult to talk about it, even though sex is a basic human necessity.
HIV is just as taboo, if not more so. People have been disowned by their families, friends, and partners for revealing their HIV-positive status.
Together, sex and HIV are massively stigmatized. But having sex while living with HIV is exactly what I’d like to talk about.

You wouldn’t believe how many people think that if you have HIV, you shouldn’t have sex at all. That’s just not realistic. And it’s unnecessary if you’re educated about HIV. This might come as a surprise, but it’s not dangerous to have sexual relationships when you live with HIV.
As long as you take your meds and you’re undetectable, there’s absolutely no risk.

“Undetectable” means that there’s not enough virus in your blood to be counted. In advocacy and healthcare communities, we refer to this as U=U (undetectable equals untransmittable). It's been a life-changer for those who live with HIV around the world.

content: This is because of amazing medicine that results in dormant virus cells that can’t be replicated or transmitted to others. This is, in my opinion, a functional cure. That’s because the virus is so dormant it’s impossible to transmit it.

This means that condoms, which can break and aren’t 100% effective anyway, aren’t necessary for safety. I say that confidently, because modern medicine has come so far that HIV is now nothing more than a chronic illness that’s not transmissible. It’s like diabetes, but easier to live with, in my opinion.

In fact, today’s medicine not only treats HIV, but it’s also used by people who are HIV negative to protect themselves from contracting HIV. This is called preexposure prophylaxis. It doubles your protection because it protects you from partners who aren't HIV negative and who aren’t on medication. They may not know they have HIV. So even those with multiple or anonymous sexual partners at risk of HIV can be protected from the virus.

content: Isn’t that amazing? That’s incredible protection!

And it’s just part of the amazing things happening in HIV research and development. Now you can get this medicine in a twice-yearly injection! We can safely have sexual interactions without the use of external preventive barriers and it only takes a shot every 6 months, whether for HIV treatment or prevention.
People living with HIV can even have children and be confident they won’t transmit the virus to their babies or HIV-negative partner.
These are amazing times in HIV science. We have come so amazingly far toward a cure and totally ending this disease once and for all.

But stigma and lack of education, along with threats to federal funding, thwart our progress and goals to eradicate HIV forever. If we’re to end this disease without a cure in hand, we must change public perception of HIV and educate everyone comprehensively.

The cure may be just out of reach for now, but we have everything we need to end this epidemic without it. If we could only change people’s minds about how safe it is to have sexual relationships with people who live with HIV with undetectable viral loads.

content: It might seem crazy that convincing people they can safely have sex with people who live with HIV could save lives and end the epidemic. But it’s true.

Ending stigma around sex with partners who live with HIV, and ending stigma associated with HIV period, could end this disease. Because without stigma, people would be more educated about HIV and fear would no longer be an issue. They’d see the powerful medication that renders the virus dormant and prevents transmission. Without stigma, they’d be willing to be tested regularly and know their status. Fewer people living with HIV would suffer from isolation and depression.
But religious condemnations of people with HIV perpetuate the stigma that people who have HIV are bad people who deserve their condition and should never have sex again. Again, that’s unrealistic.

content: In today’s world, there’s no reason to fear sex with someone who is HIV positive. It shouldn’t take a revolutionary act of courage, just a little education and empathetic humanity.
Are people still capable of that in this country? The only question that matters is, are you?
